Description: Drawing for "Ouroboros", a stone sculpture. 1994 Charcoal
Curator's comments: Label text from 2008-9 Sept.-Jan BM, British Sculptors' Drawings An 'ouroboros' refers to a snake devouring its own tail and is found as an emblematic motif of the cyclical nature of the world in Ancient Egypt, Greek, Norse and Aztec civilizations. This is a study for the sculpture carved in Kilkenny limestone which Randall-Page showed in the exhibition 'Time Machine' in the Egyptian Sculpture Gallery in the British Museum in 1995. Text from: 2008-9 Sept.-Jan BM, British Sculptors' DrawingsRandall-Page trained at the Bath Academy of Art and studied marble carving in Carrara, Italy. From 1987 he has been based in Devon where his workshop has produced large sculptural pieces, often for public spaces.
Exhibition history: 1996-7 Oct-Jan, BM NE Staircase, Gifts from BM Soc 1998 Apr-May, Ljubljana, Centre of Graphic Arts 1998 Jun-Aug, Gouda, Mus Het Catharina Gasthuis 2008-9 Sept.-Jan BM, British Sculptors' Drawings, no cat.
Acquisition name: Donated by: British Museum Friends (as British Museum Society)
